;;鲁迪·朱利安尼说：“我无法表达[他的律师]鲍勃·科斯特洛的行为对我个人造成的伤害完成。”
;

;纽约市长出身的唐纳德·特朗普律师鲁迪·朱利安尼 (Rudy Giuliani) 已;被自己的律师起诉;，要求支付超过 130 万美元的未付款项。

;
;

;;相关：;;鲁迪·朱利安尼的“暴徒场景”让埃隆·马斯克不再寻求建议，新书;

;
;

;“此诉讼只是寻求支付原告提供的法律服务的未付账单，金额为 1,360,196.10 美元，”;周一，; /robert-j-costello/">;罗伯特·J·科斯特洛;，Davidoff Hutcher & Citron。

;

;这起诉讼同样寻求利息和费用，这是对朱利安尼的最新沉重打击，他因为特朗普工作而产生的不断增加的法律麻烦 — — 主要包括推翻 2020 年大选的努力 — — 让他;他自己的律师账户;正在努力处理不断上升的账单。

;

;朱利安尼在一份声明中;说;：“我无法表达鲍勃·科斯特洛的所作所为对我个人造成的伤害。律师做这样的事情真是太可惜了，我想说的是，他们的账单远远超出了任何接近合法费用的水平。”

;

;79 岁的朱利安尼和 75 岁的科斯特洛是;长期合作伙伴;，曾于 1970 年代在纽约一起担任联邦检察官。

;

;朱利安尼在 1993 年至 2001 年间担任纽约市长，卸任后9/11 袭击事件发生后。他被称为“美国市长”，曾在 2008 年的共和党总统初选中短暂领先，但随后退出竞选。

;

;他在 ;演讲和咨询费;在9/11之后的几年里，但事实证明他与特朗普的亲密关系尤其明显成本高昂。

;

;特朗普就任总统后，朱利安尼寻求内阁任命。虽然错过了机会，但他仍然作为前总统的私人律师与他保持密切联系。他在乌克兰的工作——寻找政治对手的丑闻——促成了特朗普的首次弹劾。他在特朗普试图推翻他在 2020 年选举中被乔·拜登击败的努力中所做的工作导致了他自己的法律危机和财务困境。

;

;与特朗普一样，朱利安尼也有 ;对佐治亚州的 13 项敲诈勒索和共谋罪名不认罪;。在同一州，朱利安尼;被发现负有责任; 诽谤两名选举工作人员。

;

;除其他麻烦外，他还面临;一名前助理提起价值 1000 万美元的诉讼;，指控其罪行包括滥用权力、克扣工资、性侵犯和骚扰。华盛顿特区律师协会建议朱利安尼;取消律师资格;.

;

;科斯特洛表示，该诉讼;周一提起;曾处理过的事务包括“在纽约南区联邦检察官对被告进行刑事调查期间代表被告，在佐治亚州悬而未决的刑事调查期间代表被告……在特别律师杰克·史密斯的悬而未决的刑事调查期间代表被告”诉讼称，朱利安尼还参与了美国众议院特别委员会调查 1 月 6 日美国国会大厦袭击事件的调查，并代表被告参与调查 1 月 6 日美国国会大厦袭击事件。 “指示原告在各州和联邦法院监督 10 多起民事诉讼，并代表被告参与哥伦比亚特区和纽约第一部门有关其律师执照的纪律处分程序”。

;

;诉讼称，朱利安尼支付了 1,574,196.10 美元账单中的 214,000 美元。

;

;特朗普最近举办了一场筹款活动来帮助朱利安尼。但这位前市长的律师表示，他;正在挣扎;，据报道，前捐助者;已抛弃;他和他的纽约豪华公寓最近 ;出售;。

; Tue, 19 Sep 2023 23:22:01 +0800 Google DeepMind AI tool assesses DNA mutations for harm potentialhttps://www.theguardian.com/science/2023/sep/19/google-deepmind-ai-tool-assesses-dna-mutations-for-harm-potential

;
;;DNA 的表示
;

;Google DeepMind 的科学家们构建了一个可以预测的人工智能程序数以百万计的基因突变是否无害或可能导致疾病，以加快罕见疾病的研究和诊断。

;

;该程序对所谓的错义突变进行预测，其中单个字母DNA 密码中拼写错误。此类突变通常是无害的，但它们会破坏蛋白质的工作方式，并导致从囊性纤维化和镰状细胞性贫血到癌症和大脑发育问题等疾病。

;

;研究人员使用 AlphaMissense 评估所有 71m 个单字母突变这可能会影响人类蛋白质。当他们将程序的精确度设置为 90% 时，它预测 57% 的错义突变可能是无害的，32% 的错义突变可能是有害的。其余的影响尚不确定。

;

;根据研究结果，科学家们发布了免费的在线预测目录，以帮助遗传学家和临床医生研究突变如何驱动疾病或诊断患有以下疾病的患者：患有罕见疾病。

;

;一个典型的人的整个基因组中约有 9,000 个错义突变。在人类身上发现的超过 400 万例中，只有 2% 被归类为良性或致病性。医生已经有了计算机程序来预测哪些突变可能导致疾病，但由于预测不准确，他们只能为诊断提供支持证据。

;

; science.org/doi/10.1126/science.adg7492">;Science;、Jun Cheng 博士和其他人描述了 AlphaMissense 如何比当前的“变异效应预测器”程序表现得更好，并且应该可以帮助专家更快地查明哪些突变正在导致疾病。该程序还可以标记以前未与特定疾病相关的突变，并指导医生更好的治疗。

;

;人工智能是 DeepMind 的 AlphaFold 程序的改编，该程序根据人类蛋白质的化学成分预测其 3D 结构。

;

;AlphaMissense 接受了来自人类和密切相关的灵长类动物的 DNA 数据，以了解哪些错义突变很常见，因此可能是良性的，哪些是罕见的且可能有害。与此同时，该程序通过研究数百万个蛋白质序列并了解“健康”蛋白质的样子，熟悉了蛋白质的“语言”。

;

;当训练有素的人工智能被喂食突变时，它会生成一个分数来反映基因变化的风险有多大，尽管它不能说明突变如何导致任何问题。

;

;“这与人类语言非常相似，”程说。 “如果我们替换英语句子中的某个单词，熟悉英语的人可以立即看出该单词替换是否会改变句子的含义。”

;

;爱丁堡计算生物学家 Joe Marsh 教授未参与这项工作的大学表示 AlphaMissense 具有“巨大潜力”。

;

;“我们在计算预测器方面存在问题，每个人都说他们的新方法是最好的，”他说。 “你不能真正信任别人，但 [DeepMind 研究人员] 似乎确实做得相当不错。”

;

;如果临床专家认为 AlphaMissense 是可靠的，那么它的预测在未来可能会更有分量威康桑格研究所人类遗传学高级小组负责人 Ben Lehner 教授表示，AI 的预测需要其他科学家的验证，但它似乎擅长识别哪些 DNA 变化导致了疾病诊断。

;

;“对 DeepMind 模型的一个担忧是它极其复杂，”Lehrer 说。 “这样的模型可能比它试图预测的生物学更复杂。令人羞愧的是，我们可能永远无法理解这些模型的实际工作原理。这是一个问题吗？它可能不适用于某些应用，但医生会放心地对他们不理解且无法解释的患者做出决定吗？

;

;“DeepMind 模型在预测损坏的情况方面做得很好， “ 他加了。 “了解损坏的地方是良好的第一步。但如果你想修复某个东西，你还需要知道它是如何损坏的。我们中的许多人都非常忙于生成训练下一代人工智能模型所需的大量数据，这些模型不仅会告诉我们 DNA 中的哪些变化是不好的，还会告诉我们到底问题是什么以及我们如何解决问题。”; Tue, 19 Sep 2023 22:52:01 +0800 Global heating made Greece and Libya floods more likely, study sayshttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/sep/19/global-heating-made-mediterranean-floods-more-likely-study-says

;;2023-09-19T13:00:25Z;
;
;;致命山洪爆发后利比亚德尔纳市一座建筑被毁
;

;碳污染导致科学家表示，本月希腊和利比亚出现了更大的降雨和更严重的洪水，但其他人为因素是“将极端天气变成人道主义灾难”的原因。

;

;全球变暖导致降雨量达到了毁灭性的水平。根据世界天气归因的一项使用既定方法但尚未经过同行评审的研究，9 月初地中海出现地中海气候的可能性在利比亚高出 50 倍，在希腊高出 10 倍。

;

;科学家网络在极端天气事件发生后立即对其进行了解，他们发现，由于在漫滩上建造房屋、砍伐树木和不维护水坝等因素，人们更容易受到降雨的影响。

; < p>;“地中海是气候变化引发的危害的热点地区，”伦敦帝国理工学院气候科学家、该报告的合著者弗里德里克·奥托说。

;

;虽然研究人员发现很难量化她补充说，气候变化在这项研究中的作用比最近的野火和热浪所起的作用要大得多，“毫无疑问，减少脆弱性并提高对各种极端天气的抵御能力对于未来拯救生命至关重要”。 p>;

;丹尼尔风暴在九月的前两周袭击了多个地中海国家，并带来了暴雨。洪水在欧洲和土耳其造成数十人死亡。在利比亚，德尔纳市附近两座老化的水坝决堤，冲毁了整个街区，已确认的死亡人数已达数千人。

;

;利比亚的降雨量“远远超出了之前的水平” WWA 报告发现，“记录了事件”。报告发现，与人类没有改变气候的世界相比，降雨量增加了 50%，尽管研究人员警告说，不确定性很高。

;

;报告发现，持续的降雨量利比亚的冲突和政治不稳定加剧了洪水的影响。 20 世纪 70 年代建造的水坝维护不善。它们也可能是根据短暂的降雨记录设计的，低估了极端风暴的强度。

;

;报告发现，由于水坝储存了大量的水并且在夜间溃坝，人们面临更大的风险，导致人们面临更大的风险。几乎没有时间逃离。

;

;“我们迫切需要减少洪水风险，”该报告的合著者、红十字与红新月会气候中心的 Maja Vahlberg 说道。

;

;科学家发现，由于全球变暖，希腊、保加利亚和土耳其的降雨量增加了 40%。在整个地区，这种极端降雨现在可能十年才会出现一次。在大部分损失发生的希腊中部，现在预计每 80-100 年就会发生一次这样的事件。

;

;瓦西里基·科特罗尼 (Vassiliki Kotroni)，雅典国家天文台研究主任，也是该报告的合著者。报告将洪水描述为“突破点”。他呼吁建立预警系统和“在气候变化时代设计具有弹性的基础设施”。报告发现，地貌的变化使希腊洪水更具破坏性。由于城市化和森林砍伐，更多的人和房屋遭受洪水袭击，而吸收雨水的自然环境也减少了。

;

;生态学家、地中海气候变化与环境专家成员恩里克·多布拉斯 (Enrique Doblas)没有参与这项研究的他说：“这加深了我们的认识，即虽然气候变化可以被视为近期灾难的根本原因，但缺乏足够预防措施的景观管理会加剧其影响。”

; < WWA 研究人员警告说，他们“不能完全排除气候变化没有影响此类事件发生的可能性和强度的可能性”。他们的统计分析存在两个主要限制，一是缺乏当地气象站的长期数据，二是气候模型无法代表小区域罕见的极端情况。

;

;尽管如此，他们表示，他们对他们的结论是全球变暖起了一定作用。

;

;自工业革命以来，人们通过燃烧化石燃料和破坏自然，使地球温度升高了 1.2 摄氏度，而欧洲的变暖速度几乎是其两倍。因为较热的空气可以容纳更多的水蒸气，所以倾盆大雨可以释放更多的雨水。研究人员表示，他们没有发现任何证据表明可能会导致大雨的可能性降低。

;

;红十字会与红新月会气候中心主任朱莉·阿瑞吉 (Julie Arrighi) 表示：“这场毁灭性的灾难表明，气候变化如何影响气候变化？” - 极端天气事件与人为因素相结合，造成更大的影响，因为越来越多的人、资产和基础设施面临洪水风险。

;

;“但是，有一些实用的解决方案可以帮助我们预防加强应急管理、改进基于影响的预测和预警系统以及针对未来气候设计的基础设施，可以防止这些灾害成为常态。”

; Tue, 19 Sep 2023 20:22:01 +0800 Ukrainian market tragedy may have been caused by errant missile fired by Ukrainehttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/sep/19/ukrainian-market-tragedy-may-have-been-caused-by-errant-missile-fired-by-ukraine
;;2023-09-19T11:25:32Z;
;
;;警察和救援人员正在检查乌克兰科斯蒂尼夫卡市场的军事打击现场。
;< p>;一次导弹袭击袭击了乌克兰城市 ;据《纽约时报》报道，本月早些时候 Kostiantynivka 造成至少 17 名平民死亡;，这可能是由乌克兰发射的一枚错误导弹造成的。

;

; 9 月 6 日，导弹袭击距离东部顿涅茨克地区前线 12 英里（20 公里）处，另有 32 人受伤 ;乌克兰;，是近几个月来单次事件中平民死亡人数最高的国家之一。

;

;事后视频显示，被毁坏的建筑物和房屋中火势肆虐。士兵们抬着裹尸袋离开现场。几个小时后，乌克兰总统弗拉基米尔·泽连斯基指责俄罗斯对此次袭击负责。

;

;但是，;《纽约时报》收集和分析的证据表明，这次袭击是“山毛榉发射系统发射的乌克兰防空导弹的结果”，但失败了击中预定目标并降落在科斯蒂安蒂尼夫卡繁华的中心地带。周二报道称，“导弹碎片、卫星图像、目击者账户和社交媒体帖子强烈表明，这场灾难性袭击是乌克兰防空导弹误射造成的”。

;

;该报查看的安全摄像机镜头显示“导弹从乌克兰控制的领土方向飞入科斯蒂安蒂尼夫卡，而不是从俄罗斯防线后方”。

;

;它说，当听到导弹接近的声音时，至少有四名行人似乎同时将头转向乌克兰控制领土方向的传入声音。

;

;该报还发布了一段视频，其中在袭击前不久，导弹经过两辆停放的汽车时可以看到其反射它似乎是从西北方向飞来的。

;

;《纽约时报》称，两名要求匿名的独立军事炸弹处理专家表示，袭击现场的碎片和损坏情况与9M38，;由移动 Buk 防空系统发射;，而不是俄罗斯 S-300。

;

; Tue, 19 Sep 2023 18:52:01 +0800 Hampshire man attacked by 11ft python that crept into his conservatoryhttps://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/sep/19/hampshire-man-attacked-11ft-python-crept-into-conservatory
;;2023-09-19T09:54:42Z;
;
;;A snake being captured at Rob Byrne's home in Hampshire
;

;The owners of conservatories are used to dealing with the odd creature that creeps in – wasps, bees, moths. But Rob Byrne had a much bigger beast to tackle when an 11ft-long (3-metre) reticulated python slithered in through the window of his sunroom in a Hampshire village and gave him a nip.

;

;Byrne said he had been locking up his conservatory doors when he noticed a movement at a set of blinds. “It tried to bite me and coil around me. It nicked my arm and drew blood,” he said. “My wife and granddaughter came into the conservatory, saw it, and screamed.”

;

;Byrne, 61, a retired gas industry worker, added: “Luckily flight or fight kicked in and I managed to fight it off, whereupon it retreated and coiled itself from the windows and dropped slowly down into the garden.”

;

;The emergency services were called to the village of Bishopstoke and the python was captured.

;

;Byrne said: “Adrenalin on the day made the whole experience exciting and funny but in the cold light of day I'm disturbed that had it been my two-year-old granddaughter that lives with us, instead of me, she would now be dead.

;

;“I know there are reptile enthusiasts out there that are perfectly responsible and no problem to their neighbours or the wider public but there must be some people that are totally irresponsible for snakes to be on the loose. I did not expect to be attacked by a giant python in my own home.”

;

;Byrne has written to the UK government asking for more controls to be placed on the ownership of pythons. “Something much worse could have happened,” he said.

;

;The snake is being looked after at the National Centre for Reptile Welfare (NCRW) in Tonbridge, Kent.

; ;

;The director of the NCRW, Chris Newman, said it was very unusual for a reticulated python, which are native to south and south-east Asia, to have escaped and be at large in the UK.

;

;He said: “A reticulated python escaping is my nightmare. They are large and could be harmful to a child. We deal with lots of snakes that have escaped but very rarely reticulated pythons.”

;

;Newman said the python could not have got hold of Byrne properly. “They have more than 100 teeth. You would know about it if you were properly bitten.”

;

;He said it was “not unreasonable” that the snake had tried to defend itself and said it would have been active – because it was a male reticulated python and would have been looking for a female.

;

;Newman said it was possible the snake had escaped when its owner was distracted or someone could have deliberately released it.

;

;“It's a lovely snake – very placid. I'd like to get the snake back to its owner and understand what happened.” If nobody comes forward the reptile will be rehomed.

;

;About 3 million snakes are believed to be kept as pets in the UK.

;

;The NCRW says that this summer, roughly one in four calls about snakes spotted in the wild turned out to be exotic reptiles. In June, it received six calls that turned out to be about native grass snakes.

;

;Of the 536 exotic snakes it has taken in this year, 30 were found in the wild. The vast majority it deals with are much smaller snakes such as corn snakes. So far this year it has reunited snakes with owners in 17% of cases.

; Tue, 19 Sep 2023 18:22:01 +0800 Boy, 12, saves drowning man using CPR technique he saw on Stranger Thingshttps://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/sep/19/florida-boy-saves-man-cpr-stranger-things
;;2023-09-19T09:00:54Z;
;
;;Austen Macmillan pulls Jason Piquette, his behavior registered technician, out of his family's pool before saving his life in September 2023. The image was captured by a home security camera.
;

;At first, Christina Macmillan wasn't crazy about her 12-year-old son Austen watching ;Stranger Things;, the fictional Netflix show pitting a group of children against aliens and demons. But she's changed her mind after her son used a CPR technique that he saw on a scene from the series to save his registered behavior technician's life this past Labor Day.

;

;“I was a little hesitant about him watching it,” Macmillan told the Guardian, citing the show's science fiction-horror premise. “But I'm definitely glad that I let him.”

;

;The extraordinary story of how Austen Macmillan rescued 30-year-old Jason Piquette unfolded at the boy's family home in Wellington, ;Florida;, near West Palm Beach on 4 September.

;

;Austen began seeing Piquette about three years earlier for ;applied behavior analysis; therapy. And that day, they were swimming in the Macmillan home pool as part of their 20 or so hours of work each week together.

;

;As they swam, they eventually began seeing which of them could hold their breath underwater longer, keeping track with a timer. Austen discerned something had gone drastically wrong when he saw the timer reach about five minutes on one of Piquette's turns.

; ;

;“I knew that was way too long,” Austen later ;told; the local television news station ABC7. “He cannot do that.”

;

;A security camera at the Macmillan home recorded Austen as he swam to pool's deep end, went under and pulled Piquette out onto the steps. Macmillan said Austen tried to use the emergency unlock feature on Piquette's cellphone to dial for emergency help – but the touchscreen button enabling him to call first responders was cracked.

;

;The boy didn't realize until later that he could have also activated the phone's emergency unlock feature by holding two buttons on the side of the device down for a few seconds. So Austen, whose parents weren't home at the time, ran to the front yard and screamed, “Someone help!” – harrowing moments that the security camera also captured.

;

;Austen soon returned to Piquette's side and did the most helpful thing he could think of: he began performing chest compressions on Piquette. He recalled watching Stranger Things with his family and seeing how one character had revived another in that fashion during a pivotal scene in the finale of the show's first season.

;

;For that ;scene;, characters played by Winona Ryder and David Harbour give chest compressions to her unconscious son, who is portrayed by Noah Schnapp.

;

;The scene culminates with Harbour's character desperately beating on the chest of Schnapp's persona as the child suddenly reanimates, gasps for air, and is embraced tightly by a weeping but relieved Ryder.

;

;In Austen's case, after a few minutes of compressions, and one chest strike strongly reminiscent of the ones on the show, Piquette regained consciousness. Austen's father got home from the grocery store a few minutes later, heard his son's panicked cries, and called for emergency help. Piquette was taken to a hospital which admitted him into its intensive-care unit, where he was given oxygen overnight.

;

;But Piquette soon recovered enough to be discharged, and he was back to work by Friday of that same week, Macmillan said.

;

;The days since have produced a range of emotions, according to Macmillan.

;

;One is amazement. A ;Reddit; thread from 2016 points out how the CPR technique demonstrated in the Stranger Things season one finale wasn't standard at the time that the show is set. One of the thread's commenters speculated that perhaps the show's creators did that because of prior instances in which people have administered life-saving CPR based off what they'd seen in movies and TV shows.

;

;If that's what happened, Macmillan said, “It was definitely really smart of them.”

;

;Another emotion that MacMillan described is pride – for how her son's courage, confidence and independence had grown through therapy to the point that he saved an adult's life.

;

;“He's my little superhero,” Macmillan told the Guardian. “It shows he's more capable than what a lot of people give him credit for – and what he gives himself credit for.”

;

;She joked that her son has forever invalidated the excuses he typically offers when he tries to convince her that he simply is unable to clean up his room by himself.

;

;“I'm like, 'Dude, you ;can ;clean your room – you can pull a grown-up out of the room and perform chest compressions,” she said.

;

;For his part, Piquette echoed Macmillan in a statement to the Guardian. “Austen showed courage in the face of an incredibly terrifying and seemingly hopeless situation, and he should always know he's strong enough to face anything in life – and that he's a hero.”

;

;But Austen, his mother and Piquette have also sought to raise awareness about CPR training and preventing ;blackouts; in relatively shallow water.

; ;

;Macmillan said she arranged for members of her family as well as close friends to undergo a CPR and first aid certification course at her home on 10 September. After the course, Austen posed for a picture in which he proudly held up his newly earned American Heart Association Basic Life Support certificate.

;

;He has also taken the time to learn all the ways to unlock a cellphone to be able to make an emergency call, Macmillan said.

;

;Meanwhile, in his statement, Piquette acknowledged it was “a big mistake” trying to hold his breath underwater. He said he passed out in the first 30 seconds of his attempt and suspected that had occurred because of “hyperventilating beforehand”.

;

;“I was ignorant to the dangers, and I hope other people can learn from this,” Piquette said.

;

;Piquette also said he was grateful “God gave Austin the strength and wisdom to save my life in a time of great need”.

;

;“God will continue to use him to do great things,” Piquette said.

;

;Saying that bots cost “a fraction of a penny” to set up, Musk added that raising the cost of an account to “a few dollars or something” could put off operators of the software. He added: “Plus, every time a bot creator wanted to make another bot, they would need another new payment method.”

;

;Musk also said X has 550 million monthly users generating up to 200m posts a day. Previously, the platform had measured its user base by a different method, monetisable daily active users, which stood at 238 million before ;Musk bought the business in October 2022;.
